subject: Re: [junit] Re: what is the order of Executon of Test Methods in a Test Class
msgSnippet: If you do find a problem with running two tests and want to repeat that behavior, then make a third composite test.  Imagine testA() works fine if run after
messageBody:
If you do find a problem with running two tests and want to repeat that
behavior, then make a third composite test. Imagine testA() works fine
if run after testB(), but fails the other way around.

void testAafterB() {
testB();
testA();
}

The tests should be rewritten so that they do not interfere with each
other, so that the composite test "testAafterB" can be safely removed.

-shane

On Wednesday, May 14, 2003, at 12:16 PM, Timothy Wall wrote:

> While you may not want to depend on a particular order, what happens
> when a particular order *does* cause some interaction between tests?
>
> In order to reproduce the bug, you first want to execute the tests in
> the same order, perhaps not on a permanent basis, but at least for
> debugging purposes.
>
>
> On Wednesday, May 14, 2003, at 10:29 AM, Dave Astels wrote:
>
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, veera sekhar <sekharsv@y...> wrote:
>>> Hi all,
>>> what is the order of Executon of Test Methods in a
>>> Test Class?
>>
>> That should not be a concern. The individual tests should be
>> completely independant to avoid odd interactions and "ripple" errors.
>>
>> I always assume that the order is non-deterministic.
>>
>> If a specific order is required (more often it is simply desired, not
>> required... you should make your tests independant.. it's always
>> possible) there is OrderedTestSuite that is part of the Gargoyle JUnit
>> extensions at http://gsbase.sourceforge.net/
>>
>> Dave
>>
